componenttextpreview: No, no restatements because the combination of all three is exactly what we were doing before with the Cruise segment. We just broke the Cruise segment into three parts.
componenttext: No, no restatements because the combination of all three is exactly what we were doing before with the Cruise segment. We just broke the Cruise segment into three parts.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, I just had question on -- a lot of Howard's commentary was about bookings that have taken place since your last call. And with the Splendor and that was in the headlines pretty heavily for a few days there, did you see that temporarily impact th
componenttext: And then, I just had question on -- a lot of Howard's commentary was about bookings that have taken place since your last call. And with the Splendor and that was in the headlines pretty heavily for a few days there, did you see that temporarily impact the booking trends? In other words, in theory, and I'm wondering if without that, if we would be seeing higher numbers even, but obviously the outlook is very positive, that you're giving. Just trying to get a sense of whether you saw a temporary impact from that or not?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We run the data in a couple of different ways, and so for the -- we look at the last six weeks, booking trends are really no different than the last 13 weeks booking trends. We haven't seen any impact.
componenttext: We run the data in a couple of different ways, and so for the -- we look at the last six weeks, booking trends are really no different than the last 13 weeks booking trends. We haven't seen any impact.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We didn't see any impact at all.
componenttext: We didn't see any impact at all.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010

componenttext: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Steven Wieczynski from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about this a little bit in the press release, basically indicating that with the bad weather you've seen so far in Europe and the U.S. at this point. Can you just talk a little bit more about what you've seen in terms of booking patterns over t
componenttext: You talked about this a little bit in the press release, basically indicating that with the bad weather you've seen so far in Europe and the U.S. at this point. Can you just talk a little bit more about what you've seen in terms of booking patterns over the past two or three weeks?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Howard just answered that question basically. The booking patterns stayed the same. The only point we are making in the press release, is historically when you have early cold snaps in the north here, generally speaking, that starts to get people
componenttext: I think Howard just answered that question basically. The booking patterns stayed the same. The only point we are making in the press release, is historically when you have early cold snaps in the north here, generally speaking, that starts to get people thinking about getting away to warmer climates, and obviously, we have a lot of warm weather cruises. So we would anticipate that, that would help boost wave, but it's not something that you see instantly. But we're hopeful that, that will just reinforce what we expect to be a pretty good wave season.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, I know it's still early on, but when you look into the summer of '11, can you just give a little color on what you're seeing so far with both Alaska and Mexico?
componenttext: And then, I know it's still early on, but when you look into the summer of '11, can you just give a little color on what you're seeing so far with both Alaska and Mexico?

componenttextpreview: In Alaska and Mexico? Well, I think I indicated, I think bookings, pricing is up year-over-year in Europe, and I believe in Mexico as well. I'd have to...
componenttext: In Alaska and Mexico? Well, I think I indicated, I think bookings, pricing is up year-over-year in Europe, and I believe in Mexico as well. I'd have to...

componenttextpreview: Mexico is a very, very small segment.
componenttext: Mexico is a very, very small segment.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a very small part of our -- I mean, Mexico, I'm talking about Mexico. I'm talking west coast of Mexico. It's a small part of our business at that point in time. But Alaska is strong and Caribbean is strong and Europe is strong.
componenttext: It's a very small part of our -- I mean, Mexico, I'm talking about Mexico. I'm talking west coast of Mexico. It's a small part of our business at that point in time. But Alaska is strong and Caribbean is strong and Europe is strong.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Harry Curtis from Nomura.
componenttext: And continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Harry Curtis from Nomura.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Micky, is there anything you've seen in the recovery in global demand? I guess, emphasis on global, since the last call that prompts you to, at least, consider upping the new ship orders? And the second question is with respect to your dividend payment ba
componenttext: Micky, is there anything you've seen in the recovery in global demand? I guess, emphasis on global, since the last call that prompts you to, at least, consider upping the new ship orders? And the second question is with respect to your dividend payment back in 2008, your payout ratio was roughly 50%. And if you could give us some sense of your thoughts going forward on what that might look like over the next 12 months?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, I'd say that our new building position is unchanged. I think it's fair to say that we've said that we're looking at growing probably in the area of two to three ships a year. I don't see that changing for the time being. As far as the -- wha
componenttext: First of all, I'd say that our new building position is unchanged. I think it's fair to say that we've said that we're looking at growing probably in the area of two to three ships a year. I don't see that changing for the time being. As far as the -- what was the second...

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dividend payout.
componenttext: Dividend payout.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dividend payout, all I would say is that post the financial crisis, our board has, I think as many have become more conservative. And so I wouldn't want to preempt the board. If after this next board meeting, they agree to some sort of going forward posit
componenttext: Dividend payout, all I would say is that post the financial crisis, our board has, I think as many have become more conservative. And so I wouldn't want to preempt the board. If after this next board meeting, they agree to some sort of going forward position as far as payout ratio, we'll announce it. If they don't, they want to keep their flexibility, then we won't. So I don't want to preempt the board. It's clearly a board decision. It's something that's heavily discussed and debated, and we'll go through that mid-January and advise you of the decision at that time.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Kevin Milota from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Kevin Milota from JPMorgan.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you look at the consumer going into '11, was hoping you can give some commentary. I understand, I believe the ticket yields are expected to go up. See how you're feeling about onboard spend and kind of the expectations for the onboard component during
componenttext: As you look at the consumer going into '11, was hoping you can give some commentary. I understand, I believe the ticket yields are expected to go up. See how you're feeling about onboard spend and kind of the expectations for the onboard component during the year?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The onboard component, this year, we got about a 2% overall increase and next year, we're looking for something like 2.5% overall. Keep in mind in the first quarter, we had a couple of one-time items, which as a result, when you take that out, the increas
componenttext: The onboard component, this year, we got about a 2% overall increase and next year, we're looking for something like 2.5% overall. Keep in mind in the first quarter, we had a couple of one-time items, which as a result, when you take that out, the increase is actually a lot higher, as Howard had mentioned in his notes. So we're seeing a gradual improvement in the consumer and expecting the onboards to go up throughout the year. And we're also taking lots of steps to make things better ourselves. We're not just waiting for the consumer, adding various things on our ship, things like facial recognition in the photo, karaoke with live bands on some of the Carnival ships. We're even adding things like the keratin hair straightening treatments on a lot of our ships. So we are looking to expand the various offering and to increase the revenue yield.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then one quick one on fourth quarter capacity, what the increases are going to be?
componenttext: And then one quick one on fourth quarter capacity, what the increases are going to be?

componenttext: Which quarter?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010

componenttext: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Tim Conder from Wells Fargo.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of items here. Can you give a little more color, Howard, on what you've seen over the last 90 days in the Caribbean? You'd said that obviously, the direction overall and the yields, but you alluded the Caribbean is still a little bit weak. But it
componenttext: A couple of items here. Can you give a little more color, Howard, on what you've seen over the last 90 days in the Caribbean? You'd said that obviously, the direction overall and the yields, but you alluded the Caribbean is still a little bit weak. But it appears that the Caribbean, since your report in September, has gotten better. Just maybe a little bit of additional color on that for first and second quarter. And then back to an earlier question on the dividend, could you may be give us a little bit of an update on thinking philosophy of a base dividend versus the consideration of a maybe formularic variable component?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm getting signals from Beth on the Caribbean because specifically, I don't recall. But I would say this, in the first quarter, I would say that my recollection was that because I said late bookings have been solid actually. In fact, actually up year-ove
componenttext: I'm getting signals from Beth on the Caribbean because specifically, I don't recall. But I would say this, in the first quarter, I would say that my recollection was that because I said late bookings have been solid actually. In fact, actually up year-over-year. Some of that's got to be Caribbean on a broader sense. So I think Caribbean's holding its own and sequentially seems to be getting better in the second quarter on a year-over-year basis. So I think that's probably fair. And I think that's about all I can recall. There's so much data that we look at. But Caribbean was holding its own basically and maybe slightly better year-over-year. And that could be attributable to the winter, the tough winters or early winters we're experiencing up north and so on. But clearly, the situation is stable to up, I would say, it's probably fair to say.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Another way, I guess, Howard, to ask that question, would you say over the last 90 days has that done better relative to other geographic itinerary?
componenttext: Another way, I guess, Howard, to ask that question, would you say over the last 90 days has that done better relative to other geographic itinerary?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's done better relative to -- it's improved relative to the prior Caribbean. In other words, it's gotten better, haven't gotten worse.
componenttext: It's done better relative to -- it's improved relative to the prior Caribbean. In other words, it's gotten better, haven't gotten worse.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we haven't -- that's not the margin, because it doesn't really change very much.
componenttext: Yes, we haven't -- that's not the margin, because it doesn't really change very much.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The guidance hasn't changed, so I wouldn't -- it's anecdotal right now. The guidance -- if it was significant, the guidance was changed.
componenttext: The guidance hasn't changed, so I wouldn't -- it's anecdotal right now. The guidance -- if it was significant, the guidance was changed.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Boy, I did say this. I did say this in about the first quarter. That right now, North America brands are flat year-over-year on pricing. And there's very little inventory left to sell. We have forecasted flat to down slightly for North America for the qua
componenttext: Boy, I did say this. I did say this in about the first quarter. That right now, North America brands are flat year-over-year on pricing. And there's very little inventory left to sell. We have forecasted flat to down slightly for North America for the quarter. And I said in my comments, I put perhaps in there because there's nothing that suggest that we'll be down, but that's what the operating companies are telling us, so that's why we've kind of hedged it a little bit. It may be okay, so that includes the firming of the late bookings has helped us.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And again, as you've said also, there's just not that much left to sell?
componenttext: And again, as you've said also, there's just not that much left to sell?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Tim, as to the dividend, really as Micky said before, it's a board decision. We're going to be talking to the board in January and when we have more news, we'll disclose it.
componenttext: And Tim, as to the dividend, really as Micky said before, it's a board decision. We're going to be talking to the board in January and when we have more news, we'll disclose it.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Ian Rennardson from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Ian Rennardson from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. One, on the board meeting you're having in January, will you be discussing a further shareholder return because you allude to that in the statement, Micky? Would that thinking about share buybacks or special dividends? When does tha
componenttext: A couple of questions. One, on the board meeting you're having in January, will you be discussing a further shareholder return because you allude to that in the statement, Micky? Would that thinking about share buybacks or special dividends? When does that come back on the agenda? And secondly, on the new split into EAA, will you be giving us the foreign exchange rates at which you convert? So we get a little bit more clarity. And then if I can just slip a last one in, in the last two or three calls, Micky, you've talked about being a little bit worried about the increasing seasonality of the business, Q1 and being less profitable maybe than in the past and Q3 being much more profitable. You haven't mentioned that this time. Is that not panned out to be as not you thought it might be?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just -- I think it's basic. I'll go into the last part of your question first. I think it's kind of baked into the numbers. When we talk about -- we've gotten a lot of questions about the Caribbean and really the issues in the Caribbean are, at this tim
componenttext: I just -- I think it's basic. I'll go into the last part of your question first. I think it's kind of baked into the numbers. When we talk about -- we've gotten a lot of questions about the Caribbean and really the issues in the Caribbean are, at this time of year, created by that seasonality. It's something like 75,000 to 80,000 more beds in the Caribbean in quarter one than there is in quarter three. It's almost like the Las Vegas strip moving into the Caribbean for the quarter. And obviously, that will have an impact and create more seasonality, but it's now baked into the numbers. So year-over-year, it's 15%. It's just a fraction of that 80,000.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And really, the third quarter is key and critical quarter for us.
componenttext: And really, the third quarter is key and critical quarter for us.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the third quarter is -- last year was 2/3 of our profitability. And as we look into 2011, it's not significantly changing from that level.
componenttext: And the third quarter is -- last year was 2/3 of our profitability. And as we look into 2011, it's not significantly changing from that level.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Based on the amount of dividend questions we get, I get the sense that people don't believe that it really is a board decision. We have a very independent group of board members, and we're not going to preempt them. And we're going to let them make the de
componenttext: Based on the amount of dividend questions we get, I get the sense that people don't believe that it really is a board decision. We have a very independent group of board members, and we're not going to preempt them. And we're going to let them make the decision, then we'll make our decision and make our announcement.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The FX rates and we give the FX rates in the press release. I mean, so I'm not sure -- they're not changing just because we're giving different segments.
componenttext: The FX rates and we give the FX rates in the press release. I mean, so I'm not sure -- they're not changing just because we're giving different segments.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was thinking more about giving us the -- I suppose we're getting to the EAA. It would be absolutely even better if you could give us what you do by U.K., by Germany, your big brands over there because they are different currencies and stuff but...
componenttext: I was thinking more about giving us the -- I suppose we're getting to the EAA. It would be absolutely even better if you could give us what you do by U.K., by Germany, your big brands over there because they are different currencies and stuff but...

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we do give you the individual currencies, but as far as the -- we don't disclose brand by brand details. So it's just the three major Cruise segments.
componenttext: Well, we do give you the individual currencies, but as far as the -- we don't disclose brand by brand details. So it's just the three major Cruise segments.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Tim Ramskill from Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Tim Ramskill from Crdit Suisse.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions from me. First, was just on the unit cost side, David, your comment at the start, you talked about the better delivery over unit cost side versus what you did anticipated at the start of the year. So firstly, could you give us some c
componenttext: A couple of questions from me. First, was just on the unit cost side, David, your comment at the start, you talked about the better delivery over unit cost side versus what you did anticipated at the start of the year. So firstly, could you give us some color as to how you delivered that? And then secondly, whether you think there's upside risk to your sort of cost focus next year? And then the second question was, as you look at the price points across your range of brands, is the return to normality in evidence when you look at premium pricing versus the pricing of more contemporary cruises?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let's start with the unit cost. It did do about 1.5 better than we did last year. But I think a lot of that stems from the fact that we were able to achieve things with suppliers that was significantly better than we had anticipated in the guidance.
componenttext: Well, let's start with the unit cost. It did do about 1.5 better than we did last year. But I think a lot of that stems from the fact that we were able to achieve things with suppliers that was significantly better than we had anticipated in the guidance. Plus on top of it, this year, what we're starting to see is as the economy turns, it's a little bit better world out there. So I'd mentioned before, we're starting to see inflationary pressures in certain areas. So we are finding ways to get that out of the system and keep costs flat. Our brands are working on hundreds of different items to save cost, so we gave you what we anticipated to be the most realistic cost guidance for the year. But we're never going to stop. If there's an opportunity to do better than that, just like last year, we will find a way and we'll get the cost out of the system.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Tim, on the question of the -- I think what you asked on the price points, our premium pricing doing better or worse than contemporary pricing for our different brands. It's really a hard -- I mean, we have so many brands and whether they're in this side
componenttext: Tim, on the question of the -- I think what you asked on the price points, our premium pricing doing better or worse than contemporary pricing for our different brands. It's really a hard -- I mean, we have so many brands and whether they're in this side of the Atlantic or the other side of the Atlantic, it's hard to say other than to tell you that I think it is -- last year premium pricing came back nicely, my recollection is in North America and was stronger in its improvements than contemporary pricing. I think going forward, I think it's going to be more or less the same, that both premium and contemporary pricing are showing good improvement here in North America, as well as in Europe.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on that point about premium pricing. I guess you commented that there's still some way to go to get prices back to the '08 level. So is there an equal amount of recovery potential in both the contemporary and the premium segments?
componenttext: Just on that point about premium pricing. I guess you commented that there's still some way to go to get prices back to the '08 level. So is there an equal amount of recovery potential in both the contemporary and the premium segments?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm going to have my colleague Beth Roberts answer that question because that's something -- that's beyond my pay grade, is that what they say?
componenttext: I'm going to have my colleague Beth Roberts answer that question because that's something -- that's beyond my pay grade, is that what they say?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you got to do that, it's got to be pretty close.
componenttext: If you got to do that, it's got to be pretty close.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: She took out her calculator, which means it's very close. Why don't we go on?
componenttext: She took out her calculator, which means it's very close. Why don't we go on?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll just go on with another question.
componenttext: We'll just go on with another question.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Wyn Ellis from Numis Securities.
componenttext: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Wyn Ellis from Numis Securities.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I've got two questions, please. First of all, can you tell us what the proportion of direct sales were? How that compared with 2009 and where you see that proportion going as we move forward? And secondly, can you just repeat what you said about the propo
componenttext: I've got two questions, please. First of all, can you tell us what the proportion of direct sales were? How that compared with 2009 and where you see that proportion going as we move forward? And secondly, can you just repeat what you said about the proportion of capacity left to sell for Q3, both in North America and EAA?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Direct sales as a percent of revenue was 17% in '09. We don't have the '10 data yet. I would expect some slow growth that has last many, many years, has been growing slowly, so anticipate that, that would continue. But my guess is that it would still be i
componenttext: Direct sales as a percent of revenue was 17% in '09. We don't have the '10 data yet. I would expect some slow growth that has last many, many years, has been growing slowly, so anticipate that, that would continue. But my guess is that it would still be in the high teens.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what I said about -- go ahead, Wyn, you have another follow-on question?
componenttext: I think what I said about -- go ahead, Wyn, you have another follow-on question?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, just a follow on, on that because NCL recently, I think, said that they'd seen their direct sales go from around about 13% in 2007 to over 27% this year. Why do you think they're achieving so much more than you? And do you think you can catch them up
componenttext: Yes, just a follow on, on that because NCL recently, I think, said that they'd seen their direct sales go from around about 13% in 2007 to over 27% this year. Why do you think they're achieving so much more than you? And do you think you can catch them up on that?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob Becker.
componenttext: Bob Becker.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think they have put a lot more investment into their direct sales program. They see a lot more benefit from it. I think and when we look at our business model, it's multiple brands in different countries around the world and with different percentages o
componenttext: I think they have put a lot more investment into their direct sales program. They see a lot more benefit from it. I think and when we look at our business model, it's multiple brands in different countries around the world and with different percentages of direct business. So I don't think that were really comparable to what they're doing. I think in the last couple of years, they've made a concerted effort to get more direct business and it works for their business and that's it.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've been working very hard to make things much more efficient with the travel agent. One of the things, as we continue to automate everything with the travel agent, I think we're approaching 60% of our bookings with travel agents are now taken on an aut
componenttext: We've been working very hard to make things much more efficient with the travel agent. One of the things, as we continue to automate everything with the travel agent, I think we're approaching 60% of our bookings with travel agents are now taken on an automated basis. So we've been focusing very heavily on that in terms of reducing costs.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: What I said on the third quarter, I said that, that is really not a huge amount of business booked at this point in time. There's still a huge amount of business to be booked. We do get a lot of that business beginning during wave season, but for the busi
componenttext: What I said on the third quarter, I said that, that is really not a huge amount of business booked at this point in time. There's still a huge amount of business to be booked. We do get a lot of that business beginning during wave season, but for the business that we have booked already that pricing was up nicely in both North America and European markets.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian from Citi.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question on some of the metrics, such as booking windows and cancellations. I know you were hurt by that during the recession. Have you noticed some improvements over last quarter on those particular metrics? Has your business has been improving?
componenttext: Just a question on some of the metrics, such as booking windows and cancellations. I know you were hurt by that during the recession. Have you noticed some improvements over last quarter on those particular metrics? Has your business has been improving?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as the booking windows are concerned, it did shorten after the financial crisis and then it came back in 2009. Probably by the middle of 2009, the booking window was back to its historic levels and it's moved around a little bit since then, bu
componenttext: Yes, as far as the booking windows are concerned, it did shorten after the financial crisis and then it came back in 2009. Probably by the middle of 2009, the booking window was back to its historic levels and it's moved around a little bit since then, but really hasn't changed significantly. One of the things that everybody looks to in terms of the booking window is we're never going to get too far ahead or too far behind because we would adjust the prices. And we don't want to be too far ahead because then we're leaving money on the table. So the booking window is within historic norms and it has been since mid-'09.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And cancellations as well?
componenttext: And cancellations as well?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cancellations, yes. We haven't seen anything unusual in terms of cancellation rates throughout all our brands for quite a while for the same time period.
componenttext: Cancellations, yes. We haven't seen anything unusual in terms of cancellation rates throughout all our brands for quite a while for the same time period.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we now have a question from the line of Rachael Rothman from Susquehanna.
componenttext: And we now have a question from the line of Rachael Rothman from Susquehanna.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you comment a little bit -- I know there have been a number of questions on the booking window. But just thinking about going into this year's wave season, the 2011 wave season, and the length of the booking window and how your visibility compares to
componenttext: Can you comment a little bit -- I know there have been a number of questions on the booking window. But just thinking about going into this year's wave season, the 2011 wave season, and the length of the booking window and how your visibility compares to where you would have been at this point last year or heading into the 2010 wave season?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're -- let me just say this, we're approximately 50% booked, which is similar to where we were last year.
componenttext: I think we're -- let me just say this, we're approximately 50% booked, which is similar to where we were last year.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And overall, the booking window...
componenttext: And overall, the booking window...

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The visibility is very, very similar. The only time we had a lot less visibility was coming off the financial crisis.
componenttext: The visibility is very, very similar. The only time we had a lot less visibility was coming off the financial crisis.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then can you just reiterate your comment with respect to net yields or 2012 business? I think in response to somebody's question earlier, you made a comment about sequential progression heading into 2012?
componenttext: And then can you just reiterate your comment with respect to net yields or 2012 business? I think in response to somebody's question earlier, you made a comment about sequential progression heading into 2012?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I made a comment not specifically about because we haven't booked much of any business for 2012 yet, except maybe for some long world cruises. But that if the economy continues to strengthen as it's forecasted to in 2011 in the 3% to 4% range
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I made a comment not specifically about because we haven't booked much of any business for 2012 yet, except maybe for some long world cruises. But that if the economy continues to strengthen as it's forecasted to in 2011 in the 3% to 4% range, I would expect that with the diminished amount of capacity coming into the cruise then, that we could see some positive yield growth again in 2012.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from the line of Rick Lyall from John W. Bristol.
componenttext: And our final question comes from the line of Rick Lyall from John W. Bristol.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick questions. South America was a train wreck, pricing in South America was a train wreck, early in 2010. Can you say what you're seeing there this year?
componenttext: A couple of quick questions. South America was a train wreck, pricing in South America was a train wreck, early in 2010. Can you say what you're seeing there this year?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Very, very good bounce back, and it's doing very well. Both Brazil and Argentina has come back strongly. I think there was a massive capacity increase last year. Capacity increase this year is relatively small and the fact that a little bit more capacity
componenttext: Very, very good bounce back, and it's doing very well. Both Brazil and Argentina has come back strongly. I think there was a massive capacity increase last year. Capacity increase this year is relatively small and the fact that a little bit more capacity was dedicated to Argentina, I think helped as well, so much, much better.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that's both for the Costa brand, as well as the Ibero brand.
componenttext: And that's both for the Costa brand, as well as the Ibero brand.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: A follow up to Robin's question, where she was asking about the Corporate and Port segment. Are you going to break out CapEx and depreciation by the segments and give the same kind of balance sheet information? And just kind of a follow up, I'm surprised
componenttext: A follow up to Robin's question, where she was asking about the Corporate and Port segment. Are you going to break out CapEx and depreciation by the segments and give the same kind of balance sheet information? And just kind of a follow up, I'm surprised you didn't mention Cozumel as a facility in there. Why wouldn't that be included?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I said Puerta Maya, which is Cozumel.
componenttext: I said Puerta Maya, which is Cozumel.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, sorry.
componenttext: Okay, sorry.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's okay. Yes, you'll have each line item down to operating income, so you will have the details and you will have CapEx as well by segments.
componenttext: Yes, that's okay. Yes, you'll have each line item down to operating income, so you will have the details and you will have CapEx as well by segments.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And it appears that there's no further questions at this time. I will turn it back to Mr. Frank for your concluding remarks. Thank you, sir.
componenttext: And it appears that there's no further questions at this time. I will turn it back to Mr. Frank for your concluding remarks. Thank you, sir.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you all for your questions. And with that, we'll wrap it up. We want to wish you all a happy and healthy holiday season and a good 2011. All the best.
componenttext: Thank you all for your questions. And with that, we'll wrap it up. We want to wish you all a happy and healthy holiday season and a good 2011. All the best.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, sir. Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude the conference call for today. We thank you all for your participation and ask that you please disconnect. Once again, have a safe and happy holidays. Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you, sir. Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude the conference call for today. We thank you all for your participation and ask that you please disconnect. Once again, have a safe and happy holidays. Thank you.
